context: An investigation by <a0_0><b8_0>ProPublica<b8_0/><a0_0/> found that <a4_0><b12_0>at least 21<a4_0/> doctors<b12_0/> have been paid <a2_0><a5_0>more than <b10_0>$500,000<b10_0/><a5_0/><a2_0/> for speeches and consulting by drugs manufacturers since 2009, with half of the top earners working in <a6_0>psychiatry<a6_0/>, and about <a7_0>$2 billion<a7_0/> in total paid to doctors for such services. <a1_0><b9_0>AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson and Eli Lilly<b9_0/><a1_0/> have paid billions of dollars in federal settlements over <a3_0><b11_0>allegations that they paid doctors to promote drugs for unapproved uses<b11_0/><a3_0/>. Some prominent medical schools have since tightened rules on faculty acceptance of such payments by drug companies.
